api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: Robots and AI exist -both in concrete terms and, most especially, in the human imagination- at the contested intersection of reason and emotion. On the one hand, our intelligent machines are the epitome of reason - they are thinking machines without the messy complication of emotions. They thus exist at the apex of our rationalist aspirations. On the other hand, there is a great deal of fear and even expectancy that we will soon as emotionally-aware robots and AI. In the meantime, we relentlessly anthropomorphise machines, attributing to robots and AI all sorts of motivations, and they bear the burden of so many human anxieties and aspirations about the future: from massive job losses to (trans)human enhancement to human genocide. This paper asks, what are the consequences of this situation of robots and AI at the intersection of reason and emotion, rationality and irrationality? It is vital that we come to some understanding of how robots and AI have come to occupy this position, and not simply to dismiss the public imaginations as errors that need to be corrected: the popular perception of robots tell us a great deal about both our present human selves and our future with robots and AI.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Irrational Machines: Robots, humans and the monsters of reason
